page.title: 02DUNHAM MASSEY HISTORY.
page.content: The house was built for George Booth ( the second Earl of Warrington) in 1732 by a little known architect called John Norris. By the late 19th century the house was in a terrible state of neglect. The 9th Earl of Stamford decided that the family should move back to Dunham Massey, because the house was in need of extensive repair. Compton Hall advised them to have the elaborate stone centre piece given to the south front which is still there today. The 9th Earl of Stamford died in 1910 and the house was given to his son Roger the 10th Earl of Stamford. In 1976 at his death Dunham Massey became property of the National Trust. When the Trust took over, the aim was to restore the house to its former glory, as the 10th Earl of Stamford left it.
